content.Compliance with ethical standards: 17V.R. Sunil et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 250 (2011) 10–18 Methacholine is a potent bronchoconstrictor used in animal models to examine hyper-responsiveness of the airway, and to assess airway wall stiffness and parenchymal elasticity (Bates and Lauzon, 2007). In accord with previous findings (Nagase et al., 1994), the present studies show a marked increase in total lung resistance and a decrease in compliance in response to methacholine in control rats. These changeswere accompanied by disproportionate increases in both tissue damping and elastance, resulting in an increase in eta. Under homeostatic conditions, the lung behaves in a homogeneous fashion, despite its structural complexity (Bates and Lutchen, 2005; Bates and Suki, 2008). The rise in eta, in response to methacholine, indicates an increase in lung heterogeneity with concomitant airway restriction. This may result from regional differences in elasticity within the lung, which become apparent under conditions of stress induced by methacholine challenge. The most remarkable functional alteration noted following nitrogen mustard exposure was a reduction in metha- choline-induced increases in total lung resistance, with nomajor effects on lung compliance. This blunting of lung resistance in response to methacholine can best be explained by a loss of active airway tone. Whether this results from a loss of smooth muscle function or a failure of sympathetic control cannot be ascertained from these data. A significant blunting of methacholine-induced increases in tissue damping and elastance were also noted in nitrogen mustard-treated animals. The reduced responses in tissue damping, elastance, and eta most likely result from the inability of the airways to respond actively to the bronchoconstrictive agent. It is important to note that the loss of compliance in lungs from control and nitrogen mustard-treated rats is, for the most part similar, despite the reduced constriction in vesicant-injured animals. This may be explained by parenchymal injury and an accumulation of inflammatory mediators in the lower lung, which results in a reduced static elastic recoil. These observations are consistent with both our histological observations, and baseline lung function data. In summary, the present studies demonstrate that exposure of rats to nitrogen mustard results in significant histological changes and increases in BAL protein and inflammatory cells, along with increases in expression of pro-inflammatory and pro-fibrotic proteins. These changes are directly associated with altered lung mechanics and function. These studies are novel and provide support for pulmonary function assessment in understanding the adverse effects of vesicants such as nitrogen mustard on the respiratory system. Results from these studies may lead to the development of efficacious treatments for nitrogen mustard-induced pulmonary injury.

Because our data demonstrated that TCDD altered antigen uptake, we assessed the effects of TCDD on the T cell stimulatory capacity of inflammatory BMDCs. Surprisingly, TCDD-treated BMDCs generated normal antigen-specific T cell responses in vivo. These results were unexpected, as TCDD not only induced a regulatory phenotype in BMDCs, but also increased their expression of several regulatory mediators including IDO1, IDO2 and TGF-β3. Several possibilities could account for the lack of T cell suppression by TCDD-treated BMDCs. Though our results demonstrated that TCDD alters antigen uptake of ovalbumin by BMDCs, it is possible that the observed decreases in antigen uptake do not reach a physiological threshold below which T cell activation is affected. Additionally, TCDD may increase the expression, but not the function or activity of the suppressive mediators IDO1, IDO2 and TGF-β3. In this case, we would not expect TCDD-treated BMDCs to contribute to the suppression of T cell activation. Recent studies have linked AhR activation in DCs with suppression of T cell responses (Hauben et al., 2008). In these studies, AhR-activated BMDCs suppressed T cell responses only following LPS stimulation; immature BMDCs did not alter T cell responses. Thus, we also evaluated the expression of the suppressive mediators in BMDCs following LPS activation. TCDD-treated BMDCs stimulated with LPS displayed increased expression of IDO1, IDO2, TGF-β1, TGF-β2 and Thbs1. However, future experiments are needed to determine whether TCDD-treated BMDCs stimulated with LPS can affect antigen-specific T cell responses. Collectively, we show that AhR activation alters inflammatory DC differentiation, generating DCs that are hyperresponsive to TLR stimulation and exhibit a regulatory phenotype in vitro. Surprisingly, these BMDCs fail to alter antigen-specific T cell activation. However, further studies are needed to examine the potential for AhR-activated DCs to contribute to the generation of regulatory T cells and the suppression of T cell-mediated immune responses. One of the novelties of our data is the identification of biomarkers of exposure to TCDD and TCDD-like chemicals on a highly sensitive and extremely important immune cell population, the inflammatory DCs. Moreover, these effects were detected at very low, environmentally relevant levels of exposure. Because our results indicate that specific modulation occurs in these cells, it would be of great value to evaluate human inflammatory DCs. Similarly, our data further define mechanisms of action of TCDD on the immune system. This information may be useful for the generation of focused therapeutic approaches to treat humans exposed to environmental chemicals that can activate the AhR. Furthermore, it highlights the potential to develop selective AhR modulators that may be beneficial in the treatment of allergies and autoimmune diseases. content.CoiStatement: In a recent study, they found that RhoA promoted the gastric cancer cell proliferation and RhoC stimulated migration and invasion of the gastric cancer cell. RhoB expression, however, significantly inhibited the proliferation, migration and invasion of the gastric can- cer cells and also enhanced the chemosensitivity of these cells to anticancer drugs. It appears that RhoB plays an opposing role from that of RhoA and/or RhoC in gastric cancer cells (Zhou et al., 2011). In the nude mice model, we indeed observed RhoB overexpression in the tumors which was fed with GA solution (Fig. 7D). In addition, RhoB overexpression tumors were smaller than the positive group (Figs. 7A and B). Our work suggests a negative role of RhoB in gastric cancer progression and GA might be a potential agent for gastric cancer therapy. content.CoiStatement: NF-κB is a family of widely expressed primary transcription fac- tors composed of a group of heterodimeric DNA-binding proteins among which p65/p50 heterodimer is the most abundant form. NF-κB is crucial for regulating many critical biological processes in- cluding cell apoptosis and immune response. We wondered whether gastrodin upregulates NF-κB activity in CD4+ T cells according to the following two considerations. First, NF-κB represses cell apoptosis through inducing the transcription of various anti-apoptotic genes such as Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL (Baldwin, 2012). These proteins belong to Bcl-2 protein family which protects cell from mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, cytochrome c release, caspase-9 activa- tion and subsequent cell demolition (Llambi and Green, 2011). Ex- pression level of Bcl-2 has been demonstrated to be a pivot factor controlling CD4+ T cell survival (Shi et al., 2007). Moreover, in our system, the caspase-9 activity in CD4+ T cells was repressed after gastrodin treatment. Second, it has been well established that NF-κB is able to promote IFN-γ and IL-2 gene transcription which modulates immune response (Gerondakis et al., 1998; Weil and Israel, 2004). We found that gastrodin upregulated serum levels of IFN-γ and IL-2. To evaluate effects of gastrodin administration on the activity of NF-κB pathway, we firstly determined the effects of gastrodin on transcription levels of NF-κB responsive genes including Bcl-2, Bcl-xL and IL-2. The data showed that injecting gastrodin upregulated their transcription levels in CD4+ T cells of the tumor-bearing mice. Interestingly, gastrodin did not affect their transcription in CD8+ T cells. These observations suggested that gastrodin upregulates NF-κB activity selectively in CD4+ T cells. The unique gene expres- sion pattern including surface receptors in CD4+ T cells might con- tribute to the cell-type specificity of gastrodin, although the detailed molecular mechanisms deserve further investigation. Consistently, our ChIP assay revealed that gastrodin administration increased the interaction between NF-κB p65 subunit and the promoter regions of Bcl-2 and IL-2 encoding genes in CD4+ T cells. This observation fur- ther confirmed the NF-κB-activating capacity of gastrodin which pro- vide potential molecular mechanisms underlying its immune stimulation effect. Collectively, our current investigations provide sci- entific basis for the traditional application of the restorative food G. elata against HCC. In addition, our data also support considering gastrodin as a potential adjuvant reagent to stimulate anticancer im- mune response in clinical HCC treatment. content.CoiStatement: We do not know whether PM10 induced SREBP activation could result in enhanced cholesterogenesis and lipogenesis, since we stud- ied bronchial epithelial cells, while the liver is the site for much of the body's cholesterogenesis and lipogenesis. It is worth noting that SREBPs are normally expressed at a low level in lung cells that require lipogenesis to maintain surfactant. Deregulation of lipogenesis has been reported to cause lung damage (Besnard et al. 2009; Plantier et al. 2012). In addition, BEAS-2B cells may provide a better represen- tation of the in vivo airway epithelial when they are cultured in vitro at the air–liquid interface. It is not clear whether the results from our study represented the changes of gene and pathway that oc- curred in vivo. Further profiling of gene expression changes and ana- lyzing the cholesterol and triglyceride levels in vivo following long-term PM exposure will address these questions. In summary, our study is the first to report that PM10 exposure can modulate genes related to cholesterol and lipid metabolism, providing a new insight into the mechanisms underlying PM induced cardiovascular disease. Cellular injury results in a variety of repair responses in the lung, including removal of dying cells, repair of damaged cells, restoration of redox balance, refolding of damaged proteins, influx of inflammatory cells, cellular proliferation, and extracellular matrix remodeling. The results reported here identified gene expression patterns that are associated with temporal phases of HDI-BT-induced lung injury and are likely to mediate these types of repair functions. This analysis will therefore serve as a basis for delineating molecular mechanisms of isocyanate-induced lung injury. In conclusion, geniposide induced GSTactivity in primary cultured rat hepatocytes by a mechanism that involved inductions of GST M1 and GST M2 subunits at the transcription level. The action was mediated through the expression of MEK-1 signaling proteins and the activation of Ras/Raf/MEK-1 signaling pathway. Further detailed study on the regulation of the GSTM1 and GSTM2 genes may clarify the exact mechanism of action of geniposide. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion Genistein prevents D-GalN induced FHumaira Farooqi bymodulating the expression of various markers at both transcriptional and post- transcriptional levels. It inhibits onset of apoptosis thereby preventing cellular and tissue damage. There have been so far no adverse side effects reported with Genistein consumption. Our results strongly sug- gest that changes in the diet or supplementation of diets with Genistein may be beneficial in decreasing oxidative stress as a consequence of increased expression of antioxidant defense genes. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, our study demonstrates that GHSR is expressed in MC3T3-E1 cells and ghrelin protects MC3T3-E1 cells from serum deprivation-induced apoptosis by activating the GHSR/ERK and GHSR/ PI3K/AKT signaling pathways. They suggest that ghrelin/GHSR may be involved in bonemetabolism through regulation of osteoblast apoptosis. content.Compliance with ethical standards: ( h o w d P C C Hepatocyte Incubations I ( l o r u ( w H t v p e n w 0 a c a w 103CYTOTOXICITY IN ISOLATED RAT HEPATOCYTES TCDC or GCDC, and subsequent hepatocellular damage. As the most abundant, nonprotein thiol present in mamma- lian cells, glutathione (GSH) functions as an essential compo- nent of the cellular antioxidant defense system. Due to its very reactive cysteine sulfhydryl moiety, GSH is enzymatically conjugated to toxic electrophiles by cellular GSH transferases. Additionally, GSH participates as a cosubstrate in various GSH-dependent peroxidase reactions, protecting cells or tis- sues against oxidative damage by metabolizing toxic organic and hydrogen peroxides (for review see Meister and Anderson, 1983; Meister, 1989; Orrenius et al., 1983). These GSH-de- endent reactions form products which are usually less toxic, ore water-soluble, and efficiently excreted from the cell. owever, during the exposure to various chemicals such as edox-cycling quinones, peroxides, or alkylating agents, cellu- ar GSH stores may be depleted, leaving the cells’ antioxidant efense system compromised against oxidant-induced injury nd/or cytotoxicity (Onderwater et al., 1998; Carpenter-Deyo t al., 1991; Bellomo et al., 1987). Similarly, depletion of GSH markedly enhances the cytotoxicity of a variety of chemicals and treatments. Despite the well-known requirements of GSH for protecting cells against these models of chemical toxicity, little is known about GSH homeostasis during cholestasis resulting from hydrophobic bile acid accumulation in the liver. Although a decrease of total liver GSH has been experimen- tally observed in bile duct-ligated rats (as a model for cholesta- sis) (Pastor et al., 1997), the mechanisms and biological sig- nificance of these findings are unclear. Considering the antioxidative function of GSH, we hypothesized that hepato- cytes exposed to GCDC would undergo an oxidative stress leading to increased oxidation of intracellular GSH to GSSG, with subsequent efflux of GSSG from the hepatocyte. Further- more, we anticipated that depletion of GSH would sensitize hepatocytes to bile acid-induced toxicity, while enhancement of cellular GSH levels would be protective. The objectives of the present study were (a) to determine the effect of GCDC on the GSH-dependent protective systems of isolated rat hepato- cytes; and (b) to determine if manipulation of intracellular GSH content affected subsequent GCDC-induced apoptosis and/or necrosis of isolated rat hepatocytes. MATERIALS AND METHODS Materials Bovine serum albumin (BSA) (fraction V) was obtained from Cal Biochem (La Jolla, CA). GSH, GSSG, GSH-monoethyl ester, g-glutamyl glutamate, GCDC) as the sodium salt, 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene (CDNB), lacate de- ydrogenase (LDH) kits, iodoacetate, and 1-fluoro-2,4-dinitrobenzene were btained from Sigma Chemical Co. (St. Louis, MO). Collagenase (Type II) as obtained from Worthington Biochemical Co. (Freehold, NJ). DAPI (4,6- iamindino-2-phenylindole) hydrochloride was purchased from Molecular robes (Portland, OR). 1-bromoheptane was purchased from Aldrich Chemical o. (Milwaukee, WI). MOWIOL was obtained from Calbiochem (San Diego, A). All other chemicals were of reagent grade or better. Adult, male Sprague–Dawley rats (225–275 g) were obtained from Sasco nc. (Omaha, NE) and housed for 2–3 weeks in polyethylene cages with food Purina Lab Chow, Ralston Purina Co., Chicago, IL) and water provided ad ibitum. All animals received humane care in compliance with the guidelines f the Committee on Laboratory Animal Research of the University of Colo- ado Health Sciences Center. Freshly isolated rat hepatocytes were prepared sing a recirculating collagenase perfusion technique that was a modification Sokol et al., 1995) of the method of Berry and Friend (1969). Hepatocytes ere washed three times and ultimately resuspended in Krebs–Ringers– EPES (KRH) buffer (115 mM NaCl, 5 mM KCl, 1 mM KH2PO4, 1.2 mM MgSO4, and 25 mM Na HEPES), pH 7.4 supplemented with 0.2% bovine serum albumin (BSA), hereafter referred to as KRH buffer. Initial cell viability as measured by trypan blue exclusion was above 90% for all experiments. Aliquots of freshly isolated hepatocyte suspensions were placed in Erlen- meyer flasks at a concentration of approximately 106 cells/ml in a 37°C shaking water bath in room air and were treated with various concentrations of GCDC for 4 h. In experiments designed to examine the effects of GSH modulation on GCDC-induced cellular injury, compounds were dissolved in either (KRH) or dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and preincubated with hepato- cytes for 15–30 min prior to GCDC addition. The concentration of DMSO never exceeded 0.1% (v/v) and had no affect on any measured parameter. Similarly, preincubation of hepatocytes with either 1-bromoheptane or GSH-EE alone did not affect LDH release or induction of apoptosis. Aliquots were removed hourly and where indicated intra- and extracellular fractions separated by centrifugation at 80g 3 2 min at 4°C.

content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, this study adds to growing knowledge about genetic associations with mercury biomarker levels and inter-individual var- iability in the toxicokinetics of elemental mercury and methylmer- cury. Results suggest that five polymorphisms in GSTP1, GSTT1, GSS and SEPP1 may influence urine and hair mercury levels, though fur- ther investigation is warranted. Future research on genetic factors influencing mercury toxicokinetics should assess both major mercury exposure sources (amalgam, fish consumption) in larger cohorts using all three biomarkers (urine, blood, hair) and more polymor- phisms in glutathione related enzymes, selenoproteins, and proteins involved in mercury transport to help ascertain sources of biomarker variability and to narrow the gap between the perceived and true health risks accompanying mercury exposure. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, GA is a powerful protective agent against LPS/D-GalN- induced FHF. Pretreatment with GA significantly reduced LPS/D-GalN- induced mortality, inhibited the activities of ALT and AST, ameliorated the extent of liver injury, and inhibited TNF-α production, which might be by up-regulation of IRAK-M expression, deactivating NFκB and MAPK signal pathways. In conclusion, we demonstrated here that nectandrin B has the abil- ity to protect hepatocytes against oxidative damage through the activa- tion of Nrf2 and consequent induction of antioxidant enzymes. In addition, the activation of Nrf2/ARE pathway by nectandrin B is mediat- ed by ERK phosphorylation and AMPK-dependent inhibition of GSK-3β. Considering its antioxidative and hepatocyte-protective effects along with its ability to attenuate hepatic de novo fatty acid synthesis reported in our previous study, nectandrin B might serve as a promising candi- date to treat NAFLD and prevent its progression. Chapalamadugu et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 282 (2015) 100–107 nucleotides [(NAD(P)H, NAD(H)], in vivo (Kilfoil et al., 2013), and af- fect Kv channel gating and kinetics (Tipparaju et al., 2005). Reduced pyridine nucleotides support Kv inactivation via Kvβ1 and 3, whereas oxidized pyridine nucleotides abolish inactivation caused by Kvβ sub- units (Kilfoil et al., 2013). Based on the overall changes noted in the present study, the increased availability of reduced pyridine nucleo- tides and Kvβ subunit levels in hyperoxia state would likely cause an increase in the binding of NAD(P)H to Kvβ subunits and may alter Kv channel gating. In addition the reduced expression of NAD+ depen- dent transcriptional co-suppressor SiRT1 in hyperoxia treated mice hearts was also observed in the present study. SiRT1 regulates a wide range of cellular processes including cell survival, apoptosis, cell growth and metabolism, and deacetylation of histones and non- histone proteins (Finkel et al., 2009). Studies also showed that the mice defective of SiRT1 exhibit severe developmental defects in the heart and did not survive into post-natal stage (Cheng et al., 2003; McBurney et al., 2003). Further, the optimal SiRT1 expression is deemed anti-hypertrophic and cardio-protective, and studies show that cardiac specific deletion of SiRT1 aggravates I/R injury in mice hearts (Abdellatif, 2012; Hsu et al., 2010). Concomitant reduction of Kv1.5 and SiRT1 expression in both hyperoxia exposed hearts and SiRT1 inhibited H9C2 cells explain at least in part the hyperoxia in- duced Kv1.5 downregulation (Fig. 7 and Fig. S2). Decrease in SiRT1 in hyperoxia hearts may be due to the elevation of NADH/NAD+ ratio, which activates CtBP-HIC1 mediated repression of SiRT1 (Zhang et al., 2007). Given that prolonged hyperoxia treatment enhances redox stress in various tissues including the heart (Amicarelli et al., 1999; Bin-Jaliah et al., 2009; Brueckl et al., 2006; Pendyala et al., 2009), and that reduced pyridine nucleotides promote reactive oxygen species in an injured myocardium (Gupte et al., 2006; Ussher et al., 2012), our data point to a potential mechanistic basis for the cardiotoxic effects of hyperoxia treatment observed in this study. Previous research showed that hyperoxia treatment results in reduced body weight in rodents (Factor et al., 2000; He and Zhao, 2008; Hokuto et al., 2004). We have confirmed these findings in both our previous study (Panguluri et al., 2013b) and the current study. Although we did not measure the food intake, decreased cel- lular energy supply is a likely contributor of body weight loss, as concomitant enteral nutrition attenuates hyperoxia induced weight loss in rats (Factor et al., 2000). Also, several studies showed that hyperoxia exposure results in significant lung injury, as featured by elevated oxidative stress, inflammation, alveolar damage and pulmonary edema (Factor et al., 2000; Fukumoto et al., 2013; Kolliputi et al., 2010; Nagato et al., 2012). A recent study showed that hyperoxia exposure adversely affect cellular pathways of aero- bic and anaerobic metabolism in lung tissue decreasing energy availability (Das, 2013). In line with these observations, an earlier study showed that enteral nutritional support of rats under hyperoxia treatment alleviates lung edema through preserved ex- pression of important proteins (Factor et al., 2000). Collectively, it is plausible that the altered energy metabolism and the ensuing perturbations in cellular repertoire required for maintaining opti- mal organ structure and function may at least in part underscore the body weight loss and other deleterious effects of hyperoxia. In conclusion, we show that the hyperoxia treatment of mice leads to: 1) cardiac arrhythmia and decreased repolarization reserve, 2) ele- vated myocardial damage, 3) altered ratios of pyridine nucleotides and 4) decreased SiRT1 and Kv1.5 channel expression along with al- tered redox regulatory gene expression. Our study offers novel insights into the cardiotoxicity and ensued electrophysiological consequences caused by exposure to high levels of oxygen. Overall, we identified evidence of associations in both adults with very high exposures in early-life, and in subjects with long-term, mod- erate exposures. A variety of information fromother studies and data on biologic plausibility support our early-life findings. Major reporting bias or confounding seem unlikely but cannot be ruled out. Our findings re- gardingmoderate exposure levels are particularly novel in that they are thefirst with lifetime exposure information to show these types of asso- ciations. Given this novelty, and given the fact that tens of millions of people worldwide are exposed to levels close to this, it would be espe- cially important to confirm these findings in a population with similar exposure levels, good information on relevant confounders, and accu- rate data on arsenic exposure during all life stages. In conclusion, the present observations support a mechanistic link between ribotoxic stress and the pro-inflammatory cytokine produc- tion. In particular, the ribotoxin DON-mediated cytosolic translocation of HuR protein and its complex formation with IL-8 transcripts were critical steps in the mRNA stabilization of the gene. Moreover, regulation of transcription factors by HuR protein can also contribute to the expression of IL-8 in human intestinal epithelial cells. Future studies will be aimed at broadening the functionality of HuR protein in response to the diverse mucosal insults including ribotoxic stress in the context of the normal microflora in the gut epithelium. Acknowledgment This study was carried out with the support of “National Joint Agricultural Research Project of RDA (Project No. 20090101-030-036- 001-02-00)”, RDA, Republic of Korea. The PM issue relative to lung morbidity could remain in the forefront of air pollution research, as long as there is not a clear causative agent(s) identified. The present research suggests the importance of coarse inhalable materials, including gram-neg- ative bacterial products and possibly other biocontaminants, associated with cytokine production and decreased antimicro- bial defenses in the lung. Assessment of macrophage responses in vivo, following PM10 inhalation by asthmatic human vol- unteers or instillation into appropriate animal models, should further our understanding of the role of these PM-associated materials in asthma exacerbation and altered host defenses. Recently, Tomizawa and Casida (2002) have shown that chronic exposure of N1E-115 mouse cells to IMI and its desnitro metabolite causes the activation of extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) cascade via the nicotinic receptor and induces the mobilization of intracellular calci- um. The similar phenomenon is reported in rat PC12h cells with nicotine (Nakayama et al., 2001). However, imidaclo- prid is recovered in food (Fernandez-Alba et al., 2000) and its human intestinal absorption is not well known, although the pharmacokinetics of absorption is a major element in xenobiotic action. Thus, the high rate of IMI absorption, the production of potentially toxic metabolites by human P450 enzymes (Schulz-Jander and Casida, 2002; Schulz-Jander et al., 2002), and the presence of parent or metabolite com- pounds in food (Fernandez-Alba et al., 2000) lead us to think that IMI could present a possible toxicity to vertebrate cells and a risk for human health. The characterization of the IMI metabolic pathway and the determination of the toxicity of metabolites are the next steps to investigate the risk to human health associated with the use of imidacloprid in agriculture. Acknowledgment This work was support in part by Region PACA, France. References Discussion Acknowledgements References

content.CoiStatement: Finally, several recent studies demonstrate that although CB2Rs are expressed in relatively low numbers within the CNS, they appear to nevertheless modulate addictive properties of several drugs of abuse, including cocaine (Xi et al., 2011), alcohol (Onaivi et al., 2008) and nicotine (Gamaleddin et al., 2012).Most reports indicate that activation of centrally located CB2Rs decreases abuse related behaviors (Morales and Bonci, 2012). However, abuse of high efficacy, long-acting K2 synthetic cannabinoids for extended periods of time might result in compensatory CB2R down-regulation and desensitization (Howlett, 2005), potentially resulting in an unanticipated increase in drug use. In any case, because these drugs are rarely abused alone (Seely et al., 2011), the potential for chronic exposure to K2 synthetic cannabinoids to alter the development, expression and/or maintenance of depen- dence resulting from concurrent use of marijuana, other synthetic cannabinoids and additional drugs of abuse should be considered. content.CoiStatement: To gain mechanistic insight into the roles of SFN and H2S on regulating PC-3 cell growth, we investigated the activation of MAPKs. MAPKs are a group of evolutionarily conserved proline- directed protein serine/threonine kinases that are activated in re- sponse to a variety of extracellular stimuli and mediate signal trans- duction from the cell surface to the nucleus. There are three distinct groups of MAPKs: ERK1/2, p38 MAPK, and JNK (Wang, 2011). SFN has been shown to induce cell apoptosis by stimulating all these three MAPKs in various types of cancer cells (Cho et al., 2005; Juge et al., 2007). In the current study, we further provided evidence that SFN induces phosphorylation of ERK1/2, p38 MAPK, and JNK in PC-3 cells. H2S may mediate the stimulatory role of SFN on these three MAPKs. Firstly, H2S also induced the phosphorylation of all Fig. 7. Both p38 MAPK and JNK were involved in SFN and H2S-inhibited PC-3 cell viability. Bl PC-3 cells were pretreated withMAPK inhibitor(s) for 30 min before treatment with SFN (10 reversed SFN-stimulated phosphorylation of p38 MAPK and JNK. PC-3 cells were treated with representative of three individual experiments. three MAPKs. Secondly, compared with SFN, H2S stimulated all these three MAPKs at the earlier stage of incubation. The phosphorylation of ERK1/2, p38 MAPK, and JNK occurred at 15 min of H2S treatment. For SFN, the phosphorylation of these three MAPKs happened after 30 min of incubation. Thirdly, the intensity and duration of phosphor- ylation of p38 MAPK and JNK in H2S-treated cells were much more compared with those in SFN-incubated cells. In addition, we found that the synchronous phosphorylation of p38 MAPK and JNK were es- sential for SFN and H2S-inhibited cell viability, because blockage of both p38 MAPK and JNK but not alone reversed the inhibitory effects of SFN and H2S on cell viability. More directly, we observed that scav- enging of H2S bymethemoglobin reduced SFN-stimulated phosphory- lation of both p38 MAPK and JNK. Despite these findings, the supplement ofMAPK inhibitors or H2S scavengers did not completely re- verse SFN-decreased cell viability, suggesting that SFN may inhibit cell growth by some other pathways. It is well known that micromole doses of SFN prevent cancer and stimulate cancer cell apoptosis through induction of phase 2 enzymes and enhancing the tran- scription of tumor suppressor proteins (Cho et al., 2005; Juge et al., 2007). SFN also induces many signaling mediators, such as NF- kappaB, the activator protein 1, phosphoinositide 3-kinase, and pro- tein kinase C, etc. (Li et al., 2011). There have been many reports on the effects of H2S on the growth patterns of different types of cells by regulating MAPKs (Wang, 2011; Yang, 2011). We first showed that H2S treatment or CSE overexpression increased the activities of ERK and p38 MAPK, but not JNK, in human aorta smooth muscle cells, suppression of ERK activity, but not of p38 MAPK, inhibited H2S induced apoptosis of human aorta smooth muscle cells (Yang et al., 2004b). In HEK-293 cells, activation of ERK and p38 MAPK was induced by H2S, while only ERK was involved in the cell growth change mediated by H2S (Yang et al., 2004a). We also found that in INS-1E cells, CSE overexpression or H2S application in- creased p38 MAPK activity, and inactivation of p38 MAPK inhibited H2S-induced apoptosis in INS-1E cells (Yang et al., 2007). In contrast, increased endothelial cell proliferation by H2S is associated with sus- tained phosphorylation of ERK1/2 (Papapetropoulos et al., 2009). All these suggest that cell-type specific activations of MAPKs by H2S are required for a variety of cell fate determinations. In conclusion, our results demonstrated that H2S mediates the inhibitory effect of SFN on the proliferation of PC-3 cells by activating both p38 MAPK and JNK. H2S-releasing diet or drugmight be beneficial in the treatment of prostate cancer. This study will also advance our understanding of the physiological role of H2S in prostate cancer, and such an understanding will help reveal pathogenesis of prostate cancer related to abnormal endogenous H2S metabolism and design new gene therapy for the treatment of prostate cancer. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, our study is the first to underline the remarkable pro- oxidant role of hydroxychavicol, an active constituent abundant in betel leaves to confer maximum therapeutic benefits as it induces ROS in human prostate cancer cells thus leading to their death. Our observa- tions of this possible prooxidant role of HCare indispensible andprovide stimulus to further investigate its chemotherapeutic potential and a possible role in chemoprevention and prostate cancer management. content.CoiStatement: Currently, there is little information regarding the differential bio- logical interaction of PBDEs compared to hydroxylated PBDEs. This study found that the location of the hydroxyl group greatly influences the toxicity of the compound. Our previous study found lower bromi- nated congeners to elicit effects at the lowest concentrations; however Song et al. found that 2-OH-BDE 85 induced toxicity at lower concen- trations than BDE 47 making toxicity of these hydroxylated congeners a significant concern (Song et al., 2009; Usenko et al., 2011). Further in- vestigations are necessary to understand the full structure–activity re- lationships between numbers and locations of bromines as well as hydroxylation patterns that affect the toxicity of these compounds. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, we have shown that 4-OH-PCBs, like their parent compounds, are able to induce ROS formation and cell death in cerebellar granule cells in culture. The effects are at least partly mediated by activation of the MAP kinase ERK1/2. These observations suggest that the hydroxylation of PCBs does not by itself constitute a detoxification reaction, and that PCBmetabolites such as hydroxylated PCBs may contribute to the neurotoxicity of PCBs. content.CoiStatement: To verify the above proposals, we investigated the expression of SF- 1 and steroidogenic enzyme mRNA and protein levels in the ICA+DMEM/F12 group. Our PCR and western blot results showed that the expression of SF-1, CYP11, 3β-HSD and 17β-HSD were up- regulated in the ICA+DMEM/F12 group compared with controls. Andric et al. showed that sildenafil, another PDE5 inhibitor, promoted Leydig cell steroid production through the cAMP-PKA and NO-cGMP signaling pathways (Andric et al., 2010). ICA may also be used to treat male erectile dysfunction by inhibiting PDE5 activity and enhancing NO-cGMP pathway activity (Wang et al., 2017. Whether ICA can promote CREB phosphorylation via the NO-cGMP pathway, and thereby downregulate its target genes, such as StAR and CYP11, to regulate the synthesis of testosterone remains unclear. ICA promoted estrogen synthesis in ovarian granulosa cells (Yang et al., 2013), but whether it can promote the expression of SF-1 in Leydig cells through the cAMP-PKA signaling pathway needs further study. content.Funding: To verify the above proposals, we investigated the expression of SF- 1 and steroidogenic enzyme mRNA and protein levels in the ICA+DMEM/F12 group. Our PCR and western blot results showed that the expression of SF-1, CYP11, 3β-HSD and 17β-HSD were up- regulated in the ICA+DMEM/F12 group compared with controls. Andric et al. showed that sildenafil, another PDE5 inhibitor, promoted Leydig cell steroid production through the cAMP-PKA and NO-cGMP signaling pathways (Andric et al., 2010). ICA may also be used to treat male erectile dysfunction by inhibiting PDE5 activity and enhancing NO-cGMP pathway activity (Wang et al., 2017. Whether ICA can promote CREB phosphorylation via the NO-cGMP pathway, and thereby downregulate its target genes, such as StAR and CYP11, to regulate the synthesis of testosterone remains unclear. ICA promoted estrogen synthesis in ovarian granulosa cells (Yang et al., 2013), but whether it can promote the expression of SF-1 in Leydig cells through the cAMP-PKA signaling pathway needs further study. content.CoiStatement: In summary, we first demonstrated that highly immunogenic re- spiratory and contact chemical allergens may be differentiated by several immune markers included IgE-positive B cells, MHC II and CD124 expression, Isabelle Langonné-4-producing CD4+ cells and Isabelle Langonné-2-producing CD8+ cells. Secondly, we verified that only two of these markers, CD124 and Isabelle Langonné-2, have the potential to classify chemical allergens with moderate or low immunogenic potential. Neither IgE nor Isabelle Langonné-4 production was distinctive, although they may provide additional in- formation. While this approach has been tested on a limited number of sensitizers, it may lead to improved characterization of chemical al- lergens by allowing a variety of sensitizers to be screened. Conflict of interest statement None. References Discussion Conflict of interest statement References

Our present results highlight the potential of Pb to induce immune responses, likely Th2-mediated responses, to endogenous constitu- ents. The high expression of catabolizing enzymes, the higher levels of apoptosis and cell stress, induced by Pb along with Pb's ability to alter immunity are proposed to increase any genetic penetrance for an autoimmune disease. Additionally, the well described effects of Pb on multiple organ systems, including the central nervous, cardiovascular, and reproductive systems could be related to systemic inflammation resulting from the described catabolic activities induced by Pb. We thank the Inorganic and Nuclear Chemistry Laboratory, under the supervision of Dr. Patrick Parsons, within the Wadsworth Center for quantification of elemental Pb in spleen homogenates. content.Acknowledgement: The present study highlights that increased accumulation of collagen occurs following prolonged arsenic exposure in a dose-dependent manner and is associated with high arsenic level in the liver. Cytokines like TNF-a and IL-6 are probably associated with collagenesis and are found to be associated with protein oxidation and membrane damage caused by oxystress which has been counteracted initially by antioxidant defence mechanisms but later failed. In summary, using the 3D-SGC model, we demonstrated that DTPE induced significantly greater dose-dependent morphological changes, a decrease in cell viability and an increase in cytotoxicity compared to those treated with DNTPE. Moreover, microarray based-gene expres- sion was more altered by DTPE than by DNTPE and non-supervised cluster analysis allowed for the discrimination of DTPE from DNTPE. Consistent disruptions of steroidogenesis related-gene expression such as Star, Cyp19a1, Hsd17b8, and Nr4a3 were observed in DTPE group, but not in the DNTPE group. Our observation on cell viability, cytotoxicity, and microarray-based gene expression analysis induced by PEs demonstrate that our in vitro 3D-SGC system mimicked in vivo responses for phthalates and suggests that the 3D-SGC system might be useful in identifying the effects of developmental reproductive toxicants. content.CoiStatement: Our observations that the constructed QSAR models in this study could detect non-CAD phospholipidosis negative and positive drugs withminimal error (Table 7), lend credence to the use of the in silico ap- proach over visual and minimal property characterizations. Moreover, this means that we cannot elucidate and categorize the structures of phospholipidosis inducing and non-inducing compounds solely on the basis of the presence or absence of thewidely recognized CAD structural motif. This evidence leads us to further investigate more specific phys- icochemical parameters which may be adopted from the molecular de- scriptors used and found in common from the two different platforms (Table 6) during construction of the DIPL models. Even though both platforms use different algorithms and descriptor packages, they share common chemical properties including atomic charge descriptors, to- pological distance descriptors, etc.We anticipate that this physicochem- ical information will help refine the CAD category and potentially provide needed insight into the mechanisms responsible for DIPL. Next steps will include investigation into use of the models to explore mechanismof action, development of consensus prediction approaches, and continuous validation of models with more external data as they become known through submissions to the FDA. content.CoiStatement: 98 F. Cavaliere et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 330 (2017) 93–99 approaches could aid to differentiate between pathogenic and neutral nsSNPs and to target mutations associated to a disease. The presence of a variation in the coding region could induce a conformational change in the overall structure or in the drug binding groove, affecting binding affinity. The use of molecular dynamics simulation has provided us to analyze the impact of a single nucleotide variation on drug sensibility. This approach has allowed us to overcome cost and time problems of in vitro screening in evaluating the impact of the single point mutation at amino acid positions 256 (a Lys to Arg transversion) in the sequence of integrinα4 subunit on natalizumab insensitivity. Natalizumab is a hu- manizedmonoclonal antibody IgG4 and is approved formultiple sclero- sis treatment. By using of molecular dynamics simulation and the HINT score, we have not identified K256R as a causative for drug sensitivity. On the other hand, the HINT score, RMSF, RMSD and H-bonds results provide a clear insight of slightly higher stability of the mutated com- plex with respect to the native form. The results show that computa- tional simulations provide a useful approach in pharmacogenetics for examining the effect of an SNP in binding affinity. We should mention that at the timewhenwe started this study, the K256R variationwas an- notated as a polymorphism, but its frequency was unknown. Recently, the MAF index has been updated and it would seem that the variation is in realty a mutation. These data could confirm our results, since this variation is present at too low frequency to justify the number of pa- tients not sensitive to natalizumab. In conclusion, from the simulation and genetic data we can confirm that K256R variation is not the cause of the absence of reactivity to this drug. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, inhibition of the differentiation of D3 cells by silica nanoparticles was observed in the in vitro embryonic stem cell test, indicating that this test may be a promising in vitro tool to investigate the embryotoxic potentials of nanomaterials. The four silica nano- particles demonstrated differences in cytotoxic and embryotoxic effects despite their identical chemical composition. Taken together, our results indicate that the widespread application of amorphous silica nanoparticles may not be without any health hazards. Long term exposure of humans to high concentrations of these nanoparticles could potentially result in particle accumulation and subsequently, induce acute or chronic toxicity. A relatively high systemic exposure to silica nanoparticles might also be harmful to the embryo. Therefore, more research is warranted investigating the underlying mechanisms of these effects and the potential of these nanoparticles to migrate into the uterus, placenta and embryo. content.CoiStatement: Taking into account the present results, the proposed mechanism for the action of (PhTe)2 in the striatum of young rats is summarized in Fig. 9. We think these results shed light into the mechanisms of (PhTe)2-induced neurodegeneration in rat striatum, evidencing a critical role for the PKA, MAPK and Akt signaling pathways causing disruption of cytoskeletal homeostasis, which could be related with apoptotic neuronal death and astrogliosis. Fig. 9. Schematic representation of themechanismsof (PhTe)2-inducedneurodegeneration in rat striatum. The neurotoxicant injected in 15 day-old rats activated signaling pathways 6 days after injection. The molecular mechanisms involved PKA, MAPK and caspase 3 acti- vation and Akt inhibition, causing disruption of cytoskeletal homeostasis, which in turn, could be related with the apoptotic process of neuronal cells and astrogliosis. We hypothesize that these initial events act as the trigger for the ensuing chronic inflammation and fibrosis. What remains to be elucidated is the mechanism by which silica- loaded APC activate T cells. Silica particles may simply increase overall macrophage functions indiscriminately, or alter specific components directly involved in T cell activation. In addition, the predominance of Th2 immunity in the fibrotic stages of silicosis suggests a shift from Th1 immunity to Th2, further complicating the situation. Future experiments may shed light on the relationship between the increase in APC activity in our silicosis model and Th1- versus Th2-mediated immunity in the later fibrotic stages. content.CoiStatement: In summary, prenatal caffeine ingestion, the risk factor of IUGR, re- duces the cholesterol uptake of the fetal adrenal and has direct toxic ef- fects on fetal adrenal development. Concretely, prenatal caffeine ingestion can induce the DNA hypermethylation of SR-BI promoter and inhibit SR-BI expression in fetal adrenals, which could subsequently suppress the cholesterol uptake followed by the decreased production of steroid hormones and increased IUGR rates. We have reported that prenatal caffeine ingestion increased maternal serum corticosterone levels and induced IUGR in rats, which suggested that IUGR induced by prenatal caffeine ingestionmay related to over-exposure tomaternal glucocorticoids (Kou et al., 2014; Xu et al., 2012b). The HPA axis of these IUGR offspring exhibits a low basal activity and an enhanced sensitivity to chronic stress. Combined with our previous reports and the current study, we propose that maternal prenatal caffeine ingestion retards the development of the fetal HPA axis function by the direct toxic effects on fetal adrenal steroidogenesis and by fetal over-exposure to maternal glucocorticoids. These effects could conjointly lead to retarded fetal de- velopment and high susceptibility to adult metabolic syndrome. Our present study provided an epigenetic mechanism for elucidating the toxicity of caffeine on fetal adrenal development from the perspective of cholesterol uptake. And it also provides evidence for exploring the fetal origin of adult HPA axis dysfunction and metabolic syndrome sus- ceptibility for caffeine-induced IUGR offspring. Further analysis will be needed to confirm the long-term effect of caffeine on adrenal cholester- ol uptake and steroidogenesis in IUGR offspring. In conclusion, the data in the present work demonstrate that TIIA, CTS, TI and DHTI induce CYP1A1 and CYP1A2 isoenzyme expression through transcriptional activation mechanism and exert differential effects on activating AhR in HepG2 cells. The ability of tanshinones to induce these carcinogen metabolizing enzymes may be an important consideration in the assessment of drug–drug interaction and toxicity susceptibility associated with human exposure to the tanshinone analogs. However, additional information is needed before the significance of the tanshinone-induced CYP1A1/2 can be fully understood. Experiments with other cell lines as well as in vivo experiments in animals have already been initiated. Acknowledgments The authors would like to thank Prof. JamesW. Paxton and Dr. Yan Li (the University of Auckland) for their suggestion and kind help in English organization. We would also want to thank Prof. Fenzhi Sun and Dr. Hongjian Zhang for their thorough review of the manuscript. The authors are indebted to Prof. Geyu Liang for her kind assistance in this study. Afaq et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 195 (2004) 361–369368 addition, we have also shown that topical application of oleandrin before TPA application also resulted in inhibition of activation of PI3K and phosphorylation of Akt, activation of NF-nB/p65 and IKKa, and degradation and phosphory- lation of InBa. Our data clearly demonstrate that oleandrin could be a potent anti-tumor promoting agent because it inhibits several biomarkers of TPA-induced tumor promo- tion in an in vivo animal model. One might envision the use of chemopreventive agents such as oleandrin in an emollient or patch for chemoprevention or treatment of skin cancer. In summary, our results suggest that paraoxon induces apoptosis in cultured neurons via a caspase-9-dependent pathway leading to caspase-3 activation. While these studies need to be performed in vivo, our results suggest that activation of NMDA receptors plays a major role in protecting neurons against paraoxon-mediated neurotoxicity and apoptosis. In addition, inhibition of a-7 nicotinic receptors in cultured hippocampal and cerebellar granule cells is neuroprotective albeit at a lower level. Our results suggest that neuronal cell apoptosis may be one of the contributing factors of the adverse neuronal effects of paraoxon in the CNS. Acknowledgment This work was supported by the United States Army Discussion Acknowledgment References

content.CoiStatement: In summary, our studies demonstrate that CEES is a selective inhibitor of substrate reduction by cytochrome P450 reductase. Cytochrome P450 reductase is important not only in drugmetabolism, but also in mediating a number of key enzymatic reactions including those involved in sterol biosynthesis and metabolism, fatty acid metabolism, bile acid synthesis and heme catabolism (Henderson et al., 2003). Thus, inhibition of cytochrome P450 reductase activity is likely to have significant adverse consequences in tissues targeted by vesicants includingmaintaining homeostasis and responding to injury and oxidative stress. Of particular interest was our novel finding that CEES stimulates NADPH-dependent production of ROS, a process that may contribute to pulmonary oxidative stress. Further studies are required to elucidate the molecular mechanism by which CEES inhibits substrate reduction by cytochrome P450 reductase while at the same time, stimulating the production of ROS. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, this study demonstrates that: (1) NF-κB activation in the PVN increases PVN neuronal activity, sympathetic activity and hy- pertensive response, which are associated with the increases of PICs and oxidative stress in the PVN; and (2) PVN inhibition of NF-κB activity attenuates PICs and oxidative stress in the PVN, thereby attenuates hy- pertension and cardiac hypertrophy. This study suggests thatmanipula- tions designed to inhibit NF-κB activity in the PVN may be effective adjuncts to the current treatment of hypertension. In conclusion, we have shown that, in addition to being a classical K + channel blocker, 4-AP is a potent inhibitor of Na + channel current in neurons and muscle cells. The latter property is likely to be responsible for the effect of 4-AP on myoblast development. These findings may also provide information regarding the discrepancies of 4-AP-induced pharmacological and toxicological effects in clinical use and experimental research. Based on the results of the current study, we conclude that enhanced production of free radicals and inflammatory cytokines with the inhibition of antioxidant enzymes might be possible mechanisms underlying arsenic induced oxidative stress, which play critical roles in HSC activation and promotes the development and progression of hepatic fibrogenesis. In addition, we also demonstrated that activation of TGF-β/Smad signaling was associated with As- induced liver injury, and that suppression of TGF-β/Smad activation was involved in the therapeutic benefits of GSE. In summary, GSE, a powerful antioxidant with diverse beneficial effects such as its against reactive oxygen species and oxidative stress as well as being anti- inflammatory, might be a promising agent in protecting hepatic tissue against oxidative damage and in preventing hepatic fibrosis and dysfunction due to choronic arsenic exposure at low concentration in drinking water. content.Compliance with ethical standards: Corticosteroids have been used as anti-inflammatory treatments for a variety of acute and chronic pulmonary conditions. Treatment with corticosteroids has been investigated previously in animal models of chlorine-induced lung injury. Budesonide and betamethasone administered in a pig model of chlorine-induced acute lung injury im- proved arterial oxygenation and lung compliance (Wang et al., 2005), while budesonide treatment alone in this same model inhibited chlorine-induced increases in lung wet:dry weight ratio (Wang et al., 2002). Administration of dexamethasone in rat models of chlorine in- jury was effective in inhibiting acute inflammation (Demnati et al., 1998; Wigenstam et al., 2016). We have previously shown that some acute effects of chlorine inhalation, including neutrophil influx and pulmonary edema, were inhibited by treatment with mometasone and budesonide in FVB/NJ mice (Chen et al., 2013; Hoyle et al., 2016). Treatment of chlorine-exposed BALB/C mice with dexamethasone was shown to produce partial inhibition of acute neutrophilic inflammation and airway hyperreactivity but nearly complete inhibition of airway hyperreactivity measured 14 days after exposure (Jonasson et al., 2013). In addition, other types of anti-inflammatory treatments in- hibited acute inflammation and airway hyperreactivity caused by chlorine inhalation (McGovern et al., 2015; Hamamoto et al., 2017). In the current study, budesonide treatment inhibited multiple aspects of chlorine-induced injury evident 7 days after exposure, including Fig. 9. Distribution of airway epithelial cells after cessation of budesonide treatment. Mice were ex- posed to chlorine and treated with either vehicle or budesonide intramuscularly for 7 days starting 1 h after exposure. Lungs were collected 7, 10, or 14 after exposure (1, 4, or 8 days after cessation of bu- desonide treatment). Immunofluorescence staining was performed on lung sections for keratin 5 (basal cell marker), club cell secretory protein (CCSP; club cell marker), and acetylated tubulin (ciliated cell marker). Arrows in panels E and G indicate clusters of K5-stained epithelial cells. Arrow in panel H in- dicates a cluster of CCSP-stained cells. Arrow in panel J indicates isolated cells that stain for acety- lated tubulin. Scale bar in panel A represents 50 μm for all panels.

content.Compliance with ethical standards: The effects of corticosteroids have been examined previously in chlorine lung injury models. Chlorine lung injury was examined in anesthetized, mechanically ventilated pigs (Gunnarsson et al., 2000; Wang et al., 2002, 2004, 2005). In this model, chlorine was introduced into the airways of unconscious animals through an endotracheal tube, in contrast to the whole-body procedure used herein, which more closely replicates the usual route of exposure for chlorine poisoning. Corticoste- roids (beclomethasone, budesonide, or betamethasone) administered to chlorine-exposed pigs improved arterial oxygenation, increased lung compliance, reduced pulmonary hypertension, and inhibited pulmonary edema. Beneficial effects of corticosteroids were dependent on adminis- tering the compounds within 30 min of exposure (Wang et al., 2002). Inhaled and systemic corticosteroids appeared to be equally effective in inhibiting lung injury (Wang et al., 2005). The effects of i.p. dexa- methasone on lung injury in chlorine-exposed rats have been exam- ined (Demnati et al., 1998). Dexamethasone administered immediately after exposure and then daily thereafter inhibited the chlorine-induced increase in airway resistance 3 days after exposure and airway hyperreactivity 2 days after exposure but did not significantly affect these parameters 1 day after exposure. Dexamethasone also inhibited neutrophils in lung lavage fluid 1 day after exposure. Similar to the pig studies, our results showed reduced pulmonary edema with corticoste- roid treatment. In contrast to these former studies, we did not observe an effect of mometasone or budesonide treatment on pulmonary edema evaluated 6 h after exposure (not shown),which could reflect differences in species, chlorine exposure method, conscious vs. anesthetized ani- mals, or inhaled vs. systemic administration of corticosteroids. We also observed significant effects of corticosteroids administered 1 h after chlorine exposure, which could be an important extension of the window of efficacy if large numbers of patients require simultaneous treatment. We observed inhibition of the initial neutrophil influx into the lungs at 6 h and of the number of neutrophils in lavage fluid at 48 h, which was an overall similar effect to the previous rat study considering the different kinetics of chlorine-induced neutrophil influx between the different models (Demnati et al., 1998; Tian et al., 2008). Corticosteroid treatment failed to inhibit airway hyperreactivity to inhaled methacholine in chlorine-exposed mice, which was similar to what was observed in rats (Demnati et al., 1998). We previously reported that rolipram, a type 4 phosphodiesterase inhibitor, inhibited chlorine-induced airway hyperreactivity (Hoyle, 2010). Corticosteroids may be a useful adjunct to phosphodiesterase inhibitor or ß-agonist therapy (Song et al., 2011), as corticosteroids can potentially synergize in multiple ways with agents that raise cyclic AMP levels (Barnes, 2002; Dagenais et al., 2001; Skinner et al., 1989; Wang et al., 2004). The Homeland Security Council has estimated that an attack on an industrial site or train tanker cars leading to the intentional release of chlorine in an urban area could lead to as many as 17,500 deaths and 100,000 hospitalizations from chlorine exposure (Homeland Security Council, 2004). A disaster of this magnitude would overwhelm local health care capacity and drives the need for medical countermeasures that could be rapidly administered in thefield bypersonnelwith limited medical training. Both inhaled and systemically delivered corticoste- roids have been used clinically to treat chlorine-induced lung injury (Van Sickle et al., 2009). Inhaled countermeasures have disadvantages, as these could be difficult to administer to victims who were uncon- scious or those with lung injury that limited the penetration of inhaled drugs. Systemic corticosteroids are typically given intravenously, but this method is impractical for initial field use with large numbers of ca- sualties because of the time and expertise required. Our results show proof-of-principle for systemic administration of corticosteroids in treating chlorine-induced lung inflammation and pulmonary edema. Future studieswill investigate the feasibility of developing formulations that could be used for intramuscular administration of corticosteroids, either alone or in combination with other potential countermeasures, thereby providing a rapid and simple delivery method.

content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, the findings of the present study suggest that KYKZL-1 is a potent inhibitor of LPS-induced NO, PGE2 and LTB4 in macrophage cells and that it inhibits the LPS-induced expression of iNOS, COX-2 and 5-LOX at the mRNA and protein levels. Moreover, these inhibitory effects of KYKZL-1 were found to be associated with suppression of phosphorylation of MAPKs and NF-kB inactiva- tion via the blockade of IκB-α phosphorylation and inactivation of IKKs. Since NF-kB is a transcription factor that regulates the transcriptions of many genes associated with inflammation, the above results also suggest that KYKZL-1 contain remarkable anti- inflammatory activity with an improved gastric profile and may present a potential promising safer chemical alternative for tradi- tional NSAIDs and selective COX-2 inhibitors for the treatment of in- flammatory diseases. In summary, the present studies demonstrate that a stable congener of AEA, F-Me-AEA, exhibits cannabinoid-like activity at both the biochemical and cellular level in mouse leukocytes. These studies suggest that the short-lived immunomodulatory activity observed with AEA might be closely associated with its lability in biological systems. In addition, F-Me-AEA represents yet another cannabinoid compound that exerts potent effects on NF-AT DNA binding activity, further supporting the notion that NF-AT is a critical target of suppression by cannabinoids. The cannabinoid-induced suppression of NF-AT activity likely contributes to the pleiotropic effects of these compounds in lymphocytes. content.Acknowledgement: In conclusion, ocular hypertension in rats resulted in ER stress, nitrative stress, caused apoptosis and altered VEPs. Inhibition of N- SMase activity in the presence of EIOP significantly reduced nitrative stress and apoptosis and normalized VEPs. Our data suggests that NOS2 can be regulated by N-SMase in retinal tissue and that N-SMase inhibition can potentially be a pharmaceutical target in the prevention of glaucoma. content.CoiStatement: In summary, our data show that DADS inhibits LPS-induced NO and PGE2 production by suppressing iNOS and COX-2 mRNA and protein expression in BV2 microglial cells. DADS also inhibits the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines (TNF-α, IL-1β and MCP-1) by suppressing their expression levels. These effects are mediated by attenuation of NF-κB translocation from the cytoplasm to the nucleus, which is accompanied by blocking of AP-1, PI3K/Akt and MAPK pathways. This suggests that DADS is of importance in the development of neuroprotective agents to treat inflammatory and neurodegenerative diseases. In conclusion, we demonstrated in this study that inorganic sodium arsenite induced the abnormal generation of the HLA-DR and CD14 highly positive nonadhesive macrophages, As-Mp, from human peripheral blood mono- cytes at nM levels with GM-CSF in vitro. This work may have implications in both chronic arsenic poisoning and in the chemotherapeutic use of this remarkable metalloid. Acknowledgments We express our thanks to Dr. Michael P. In conclusion, results of the present study clearly show that the sequence of exposure to chlorpyrifos and methyl parathion can markedly influence the expression of cholin- ergic toxicity. Moreover, less toxicity was noted in rats exposed to both OP insecticides concurrently than in rats treated sequentially with CPF first. Differential interaction with sites of bioactivation and other macromolecular tar- gets are likely to be critical factors contributing to se- quence-dependent toxicity of these OP insecticides. Al- though in vitro studies with OP mixtures may give information on the nature of interaction, further in vivo studies may be critical for evaluating a differential role of toxicokinetic and toxicodynamic modulating factors in such interactive toxicity. Acknowledgments This study was partially supported by STAR research Results Discussion Acknowledgements References

content.Disclosure: 79B.L. Williams et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 233 (2008) 76–80 Given the inability of the researchers to agree on protocol, the IRB was asked to review the matter. The IRB required the principle investigator to complete a standard adverse event report. This posed the third major complication for the study; we were being asked to report and designate these findings as an “adverse” occurrence irrespective of the lack of evidence supporting such a designation. An adverse event is commonly defined as any harm experienced by a subject that resulted during the course of his participation. Usually applied to clinical trials, adverse event reporting is meant to provide the IRB with the ability to monitor unexpected events in order to maintain reasonable level of protection to subjects. Although the initial results were unexpected, there was clearly inadequate evidence to conclude that the subjects were at an acute risk. Nonetheless, we submitted the report to the IRB. After review, the IRB supported the retesting of the initial and duplicate samples prior to disclosure and directed the researchers to devise a disclosure plan in the event the initial results were confirmed. The samples were sent to the CDC for reanalysis which confirmed our suspicions. Only three of the samples had detectable amounts of mercury in the blood. After receiving these results, we worked with our initial chemists to identify the source of error in the original analysis. Consequently, we concluded that the initial samples had become contaminated with an external mercury source. Given mercury’s propensity to stick to all surfaces, special precautions were taken to insure that contamination from sample to sample or from standard to sample did not occur during analysis. However, these precautions failed because the system used to de-ionize the water for dilution of the samples had begun releasing solid particulate and measurable breakthrough occurred. After diluting the samples, small differences were detected between the contaminated samples and non-contaminated samples. This contamination was additionally problematic to detect because it did not affect all samples equally and the quality control samples were all within specification. Aw / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 204 (2005) 320–328 327 differential cellular responses to GSH/GSSG redox imbal- ance could contribute to a loss of intestinal integrity and promote pathogenesis of chronic gut disorders like inflammatory bowel disease. Evidence that the intestinal epithelium is capable of transporting luminal GSH to augment intracellular peroxide catabolism and the notion that the etiology of chronic gut pathologies may be directly linked to an early loss of mucosal redox balance suggest that dietary strategies for intestinal redox maintenance would be a viable consideration in chronic gut disease management. In conclusion, our results presented herein demonstrated that repeated intravaginal administration of spermicidal VDACAC and VDDTC via a gel-microemulsion at concentrations nearly 500- and 2000-fold higher than their respective in vitro sper- micidal EC50 values showed no marked vaginal irritation, mucosal toxicity, or systemic absorption of vanadium in the rabbit model. Because of their potent spermicidal activity, low irritation potential, and lack of systemic toxicity, vanadocenes have particular clinical potential as a new class of non-deter- gent-type vaginal contraceptive agents. content.Acknowledgement: Interpretation of the results described in this report is complicated by multiple and competing factors. Although the effect of ionic environment on the biological availability of HD active species (to either critical extracellular membrane or intracellular (DNA?) components) must certainly impact HD toxicity, it does not seem likely that it is a major contributing factor to the overall toxicity observed in these studies. Rather, the data support the hypothesis that the early events that lead to HD toxicity are closely regulated by monovalent ionic (most especially anionic) environment at biochem- ical sites. The inhibition of NHE does not appear to be causal to HD- induced toxicity. However, given the profound and persistent cytosolic acidification induced by HD, as well as its time- and concentration-dependent inhibitory effects on pHi regulatory mechanisms, it appears necessary to establish the importance of HD-induced effects on other antiporter systems involved in intracel- lular pH regulation. Studies are currently underway to investigate the importance of these systems in determining the toxicity of HD in the target cells of HD-induced vesication, namely human basal skin keratinocytes. All experiments were perfor 250 μM. a Rates are calculated per nmol P450 (kcat). b Based on the rates of formation of 1-naphthol. c Rates at 250 μM substrate concentration. selective approaches for obtaining target portions of the respiratory tract of both rodents and non-human primates, it is possible that a very few cells within the primate nasal or airway epithelium could catalyze high rates of naphthalene turnover which are ‘diluted’ by in- active proteins which then contribute to the denominator in the ac- tivity measurements. Earlier studies have shown that CYP2F2 is highly localized to Clara cells of the mouse but little information of specific sites of protein localization is available in other species (Buckpitt et al., 1995). Unfortunately, relatively lower specific activi- ties of naphthalene turnover were observed in isolated mouse Clara cells (Chichester et al., 1994) than in whole dissected airway explants leading to the conclusion that isolated cells likely did not provide a quantitatively robust estimate of naphthalene turnover in target cells. The possibility that metabolites are generated in other metabol- ically active tissues such as the liver which circulate to the lung can- not be ruled out. Finally, dissected airways of primates generate proportionally high amounts of protein bound metabolites (Boland et al., 2004) and several of the adducted proteins isolated from mon- key nasal epithelial incubations are identical to those isolated from rat nasal olfactory epithelial incubations (DeStefano-Shields et al., 2010). The reasons for the apparent mismatch between slow rates of naphthalene metabolism with easily detectable formation of pro- tein adducts are not obvious. Decreased CD69 expression is typical for type 2 or regulatory CD4 + T cells. However, DO11.10 mice were on a BALB/c background which tends toward a Th2 response even under normal conditions. Although Pb allo-enhancement has been observed regardless of the haplotype of the responding strain (McCabe et al., 2001), the phenotype of responding T cells was not assessed in this study. It will be important in the future to characterize the phenotype of allo-reactive T cells in the presence and absence of Pb. Acknowledgments This work was supported by National Institutes of Health Discussion Acknowledgments References

By contrast, the role of Pb ions is less clear. It had been hypothesized that Pb ions might induce dicentric chromo- some aberrations (Wise et al., 1994) or that they might be mitogenic allowing cells to escape the cytotoxic effects of chromate (Carlisle et al., 2000; Wise et al., 2002, 2003, 2004a). In previous reports, we found that Pb ions were not genotoxic in human bronchial cells (Wise et al., 2004a). In this report, we find that Pb does not affect the growth of human lung cells and does not cause cells to escape the cytotoxic effect of chromate ions. Thus, the likely hypoth- eses that would explain the greater carcinogenicity of particulate chromate is either that the cation (such as Pb) interferes with DNA repair or perhaps the difference is a consequences of chronic exposure to chromate ions and the cation plays no mechanistic role. Future research is aimed at exploring these two hypotheses. Acknowledgments We would like to thank Dr. Samantha Langley-Turn- baugh for the use of the ICP, Shawn Holt and Lynne Elmore for their expertise and assistance in creating the hTERT immortalized cell line and Geron Corporation for the use of the hTERT materials. This work was supported by NIEHS grant ES10838 (J.P.W.) and the Center for Integrated and Applied Environmental Toxicology at the University of Southern Maine. References Discussion Acknowledgments References

In summary, it was shown that PC-SOD protects against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity in the mouse when administered 15 min before doxorubicin. PC-SOD is well tolerated and shows no signs of toxicity even at very high doses. Very importantly, in our studies, PC-SOD did not show any sign of interference with the antitumor effect of doxorubicin. These data suggest that PC-SOD is a suitable candidate for further investigations on the prevention of doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity. Acknowledgments We thank Seikagaku Corporation (Tokyo, Japan) for providing us with lecithinized recombinant human super- oxide dismutase (PC-SOD) and Leo Baars, Nicole Bitsch, Gregorio Fazzi, Caroline Erkelens, Hennie Schlüper, and Saskia Hulscher for their skillful technical assistance. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, we demonstrated that lipocalin 2 is a new GADD153 target gene and participating ER stress-induced apoptosis. This find- ing provides a new factor for GADD153-mediated apoptosis under ER stress. Clarification of factors that lead lipocalin 2 to become an apoptosis stimulator is a promising direction for anticancer drug development. content.CoiStatement: To summarize our data, we observed that magnesium lithosper- mate B (LAB) had an anti-apoptotic effect on TNF-γ and IL-1β-induced apoptotic pancreatic β-cells in vitro and a preventive effect on the development of type 2 diabetes in an OLEFT animal model in vivo. In this study, the anti-apoptotic effects of LAB were demonstrated by the down-regulation of the apoptotic pathways of c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase (JNK) and p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), and the up-regulation of the anti-apoptotic pathway of Nrf2/HO-1 and Sirt1 expression. Further clinical studies are needed to evaluate the use of LAB for type 2 diabetes treatment. Conflicts of interest The authors report no conflicts of interest. content.CoiStatement: In summary, the data support the conclusion that NP260 is directly toxic to the liver, particularly in the dog and in humans, with the rat being relatively insensitive to its hepatotoxic effects. While the source of continuous ALT elevations remains elusive, the biomarker data and pathology findings support an initial liver injury followed by adaptation and repair. Based on the relative sensitivity of human hepatocytes to NP260 toxicity, it is reasonable to assume that NP260 would be directly liver toxic in the clinic at the doses tested, while the potential for adap- tation in humans is unknown. Taken together, analysis of novel bio- markers along in vitro hepatocyte studies provided useful information in predicting a potential for NP260 to cause liver toxicity in the clinic.
